body: Nearly $5 billion in development projects in New York City have been delayed or canceled because of the economic crisis, an extraordinary body blow to an industry that last year provided 130,000 unionized jobs, according to numbers tracked by a local trade group. The setbacks for development -- perhaps the single greatest economic force in the city
title: DOWNTURN ENDS CITY'S BOOM TIME IN CONSTRUCTION

body: Under the no-stone-left-unturned set of new taxes, fines and fees proposed on Tuesday by Gov. David A. Paterson to help balance the budget, a Château Lafite or a Budweiser could soon cost more to sip. But David Britten isn't concerned. As a matter of faith, Mr. Britten, 58, who is better known as known as Rama Dass, the spiritual leader of the
title: When the Ascetic Life Looks Like a Smart Financial Move

body: 'THE CHARLIE BROWN CHRISTMAS' Linus's grungy blanket, Charlie Brown's hairs, Lucy's attitude: the whole Peanuts gang will become three-dimensional this weekend when the young theater company Pig Brooch stages a verbatim re-enactment of ''A Charlie Brown Christmas,'' the perennial, and perennially beloved, TV special. title: Spare Times

body: The uniformed traffic officer was standing at a deli counter when a man approached her and asked, ''Are you on drugs?'' Taken aback, she replied, ''What is your problem?'' The man then proceeded to berate her for having parked in front of a fire hydrant outside the deli, even while fire engines responding to an emergency had stopped down the block.
title: Officers Become Accidental YouTube Stars

title: BUY OF THE WEEK/BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; $875,000

body: TALK to a bankruptcy lawyer for a few minutes -- just pick a firm from one of the big ads in the phone book -- and you'll hear the stories of outlandish fiscal recklessness, of clients with moderate incomes and three mortgaged houses, or with multiple credit cards and tens of thousands of dollars in debt. The lawyers have been at the center of the
title: DISPATCHES; What's Left When the Last Penny's Gone

body: Only 200 feet from Fulton Street's thumping hip-hop music and fast food outlets, dozens of votive candles burned amid stuffed animals and a brick wall of graffiti sentiments on Kingston Avenue. It was a makeshift memorial to Mario Smith, a 14-year-old boy who had been sitting with friends on a stoop before he was fatally shot. Fourteen blocks away,
title: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT JOURNAL; A Neighborhood in Transition, Sometimes Uneasily

body: An e-mail message arrived in my in-box Monday afternoon with the news that Devin Harris of the Nets was now featured on an 80-by-60-foot billboard above the ESPN Zone on 42nd Street and Broadway. That was preceded by another announcing Harris as the N.B.A.'s Eastern Conference player of the week. If Harris continues on the scoring binge he has been
title: Harris's Play Sweetens the Kidd Trade

body: BRYAN DRURY was hardly thinking of buying an apartment. But when he and his parents happened to see a subway ad for Oro Condominiums in downtown Brooklyn in the spring of 2007, ''that planted the seed,'' Mr. Drury said. His parents were in town then for his graduate school graduation from the New York Academy of Art, and they thought a condo might
title: THE HUNT; Hello, Doorman

body: In the heart of Midtown, a yearlong project to build a new subway entrance provides a nightly feast for sidewalk superintendents and urban archaeologists. During the day, at least on weekdays, much of the underground work at Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street is hidden by steel plates weighing more than two tons each. They are removed about 10 p.m.,
title: MIDTOWN JOURNAL; New Subway Entrance Opens Window to an Old, Coal-Heated New York

body: HOLIDAY MARKETS Ah, the holidays. That warm and fuzzy time when you suffer from the post-traumatic stress that comes from spending all of your free time fighting (sometimes literally) to buy gifts you can't afford. This year should be different, and not just because the economy has thinned the crowds and left you with fewer people to battle. New
title: Spare Times

title: Spare Times

title: LONG ISLAND CITY JOURNAL; When Home Is More Like a Cruise Ship

title: Spare Times

body: The former director of a Brooklyn nonprofit agency was arrested on Wednesday on charges that he stole more than half a million dollars in federal aid that was supposed to go to buy food for poor children. The man, Andre A. Lewis, was executive director of the Better Brooklyn Community Center, an agency that ran after-school programs and a day care
title: Man Charged in Theft of Food Aid

body: In one picture, Michael Mineo is wearing a mullet wig. He seems happy, almost carefree, as he clowns around in a drama sketch at McCaskey High School here. In the other, he looks tortured, pain etched on his face, his tattooed arms visible in the Brooklyn hospital bed where he had gone after being, by his account, horribly assaulted by the police.
title: A Life of Loss and Missteps

body: After Philippe de Montebello retires at year's end as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, his sonorous voice will no longer be a signature presence on the Met's audio guides. title: INSIDE ART; Familiar Voice, Different Home

body: Among office tenants, bargain hunting is back in style. After years of paying skyrocketing rents in Manhattan, some companies have decided to cross the East River. title: SQUARE FEET; Office Tenants Flee Manhattan Rents for Brooklyn

body: New York Comedy Festival With a few exceptions, the lineup at the fifth annual New York Comedy Festival is not inherently political. No matter who wins, will the comedians -- who
title: Spare Times

body: On bodies already richly etched with ink, the artists who work at the Jiggaman tattoo parlor in Downtown Brooklyn wear small Chinese characters that mean ''family'' on the heels of their palms. It is not uncommon for them to arrive at work together. Ashley Loney, 20, walked in two years ago to get a tattoo and has been hanging out ever since. Other
title: For an Accuser Of the Police, A Family of Sorts

body: The taxicabs parked outside the train station here all carried campaign advertisements for a veteran Republican state senator, Caesar Trunzo. But as night fell on a neighborhood of weathered ranch homes jammed up against the Long Island Expressway, the door-knocking was all being done for his Democratic challenger, Brian Foley, by employees of yet
title: A Small Party Pushes To Be a Statewide Force

body: Grand juries are usually presented with a set of witnesses and facts neatly packaged by the district attorney, with the decision to indict often an easy one. This is not the case with the special investigative grand jury meeting now to examine the claim of a Brooklyn man that police officers sodomized him with a piece of equipment on Oct. 15. About
title: Grand Jury Weighs Accounts of Police and Brooklyn Man

body: FROM one angle -- say, from the corner of Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street -- downtown Brooklyn might seem to be a horrible place to live. Look over one shoulder and there's the abandoned Brooklyn House of Detention, which the city has considered revitalizing as a combination jail and multiuse project. Over the other shoulder are several lanes
title: HABITATS; Finding the Best Side of a Neighborhood

body: The case of a Brooklyn man who says he was sodomized by police officers at a subway station last week presents two sets of assertions, and they are hard to reconcile. According to a law enforcement official briefed on the investigation, witnesses who saw officers confront the man, Michael Mineo, on Oct. 15 at the Prospect Park station on suspicion
title: In Case of Man Alleging Brutality, Many Conflicting Claims

body: Randy Levine, the president of the Yankees, told a Congressional hearing Friday that if the city had not issued tax-exempt financing for the team's new stadium, it would have left town. ''It's been no secret for many years'' that the team would move if it could not save tens of millions of dollars on financing with tax-free bonds, Levine told the
title: Yankees Say They Would Have Left Bronx if Pushed

body: Brooklyn prosecutors and police internal affairs officers are investigating allegations that uniformed New York City police officers beat and sodomized a man in a Brooklyn subway station, officials and lawyers for the man said on Thursday. The lawyers identified the man as Michael Mineo, 24, of Brooklyn, an employee at a Brooklyn tattoo parlor. He
title: Police Investigate Brooklyn Man's Allegation of Brutality

title: Gifts for Skittish Buyers

body: CULTURE can be expensive, no matter which way the Dow is pointing. But in belt-tightening times, the cost of enjoying the arts in New York might seem particularly daunting. Take Broadway, for example. The average price paid for a ticket last week was $76, according to the Broadway League, which represents theater owners and producers. For many
title: CHEAP SEATS; Bad Times, Good Prices

She has started a Web site and has held a number of fund-raising events, which have taken in more than $50,000. But with the current turbulence
title: Council Candidates Are Left in Limbo Over Term Limits

body: IN her 19 years as a corrections officer on Rikers Island, Barbara Williams has been trapped in a mess hall with rioting inmates and thrown against an iron gate by a man twice her size who left her with a fractured shoulder. But nothing makes her wince like remembering the time an inmate commented on the way her hips swayed ever so slightly beneath
title: The Changing of the Guard

body: It was a grueling day of nonstop activity for United States Representative Edolphus Towns. title: Accused of Being Out of Touch, a 25-Year Congressman Campaigns for Dear Life

body: Squeezing a large urban retail center onto a small, oddly shaped building site is almost never easy in New York, and the task can become particularly daunting when a prominent national retailer decides to make the center a home for its largest store anywhere. title: Big Stores in Odd Shapes Arriving in Brooklyn

title: N.F.L. ROUNDUP; Negotiations With Allianz On Naming Of Stadium

body: THERE are some New York neighborhoods where the population is expected to be heavily Asian-American -- say, in Chinatown, or in Flushing, Queens, or in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Those areas have long been defined by the first-generation immigrants from China and Korea who fill the busy streets lined with ethnic markets and restaurants. But developers
title: A New Generation Moves On, But Not Too Far

author: Jeffrey M. Zupan is a senior fellow for transportation at the Regional Plan Association.
body: THIRTY years ago the New York City transit system was in shambles. Derailments and track fires were commonplace. Graffiti covered nearly every visible surface. Canceled trains were an everyday occurrence. All of this was the result of neglect that was politely called deferred maintenance. The solution was a package of fees and taxes that rescued
title: OP-ED CONTRIBUTOR; Give That Bus a Makeover

body: Alison Borzacchiello, a stay-at-home mother from Queens, needed something new to wear to a wedding, so she set out a few weeks ago for Estelle's Dressy Dresses in Farmingdale, N.Y. That was hardly momentous. What made it worthy of note is that she did not take her 11-year-old son, Nicky, along. He has just reached that awkward age when he is old
title: Children Left Alone At Home, Worriedly

body: The large white bandage covering Enois Malbranche's right eye hid the hole left by a young woman in his taxi who had demanded his money, pointed a gun at his face and pulled the trigger. title: Cab Driver Recalls Shot Destroying His Right Eye

title: Private School's New Neighbor Is Too Close for Some Parents' Comfort

body: After weeks of bad news, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey can finally declare a victory at ground zero. The authority has reached a tentative agreement to help rebuild St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church on Liberty Street, clearing the way for the long-stalled work to begin on the foundation walls at the south end of the 16-acre site.
title: Agency in Tentative Accord With Ground Zero Church

title: SPORTS BUSINESS; Citigroup Puts Its Money Where Its Name Will Be

Part of Animal Antics Weekend, the kitchen detail is a
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: FOR CHILDREN 'CINDERELLA' (Saturday) Forget about a wicked stepmother and a pumpkin-turned-coach. This new production by Youth on Target Theater Company is drawn from the Italian tradition, in which Cinderella's mother is very much alive, and Cinderella is not so much persecuted as immobilized by grief. (Her father has died.) For ages 7 and older,
title: For Children

body: The bad old days of subway turnstile jumping may be gone, but the fine for trying to sneak a free ride went up on Monday anyway, to $100 from $60 -- the first increase in nearly a quarter century. From Jan. 1 through July 6 this year, transit police issued 41,090 tickets for fare evasion and arrested an additional 8,437 people for not paying the
title: A Bigger Penalty for Riders Who Cheat on the Fare

body: HE was there to meet his bride when the ship docked at New York Harbor in the late winter of 1946, driving up in a black Buick with a bouquet for her on the dashboard. They had met at a pub on Kings Road in Chelsea called the Lord Nelson. He was an American soldier; she was 16, an English girl from Battersea. They married in London at the end of
title: Band of Sisters

body: AROUND TOWN THE FIFTH OF JULY When the oohing and aahing, not to mention the eating, are over, it might be time for a holiday reality check. title: Spare Times

body: The story of the tiny St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church and its efforts to rebuild after the collapse of the World Trade Center is one of well-intentioned promises that led to endless negotiations, design disputes, delays and mounting costs. It is, in other words, a microcosm of the seven-year, $16 billion, problem-plagued effort to reconstruct
title: Church's Rebuilding Troubles Typify Ground Zero Delays

body: To the Editor: I was so excited to read ''A Circle of Women, Discovered on a Stoop'' (New York Observed, June 22), about the author's discovery of the Rumer Godden novel ''Kingfishers Catch Fire'' on a stoop in Brooklyn Heights. I had just bought that edition of the book, as I am a Godden fan and am trying to make my way slowly through all her
title: LETTERS; Journey To a Prom of Dreams | On A Literary Treasure Left On a Stoop

body: ''The New York City Waterfalls,'' Olafur Eliasson's work of public art, will be even more public than ''The Gates'' were. After all, you had to go to Central Park to see ''The Gates.'' For many New Yorkers, and visitors to New York, it will be hard to miss the waterfalls, which officially opened Thursday and run until Oct. 13. The work consists of

title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Brooklyn Gains TKTS

body: WHILE condominium developers across the country are trying to unload thousands of apartments that they can't sell, some builders in Brooklyn have found the real estate equivalent of a golden parachute. title: They (The New) Brooklyn

body: Correction Appended AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites RENEGADE CRAFT FAIR Let's face it, hierarchy is passé. Want to watch TV? No need to wait for the networks; just shoot something with your friends and edit the video. How about some music? Go to iTunes and create your own mix. Or a scarf? Pick up some knitting needles, and, well, you get the idea.

body: ROMAN LUBA first saw Renata Bokalo at a Ukrainian summer camp in upstate New York. He was 8 years old. She was 4. ''My mother was the nurse,'' said Ms. Bokalo, who is now 34, ''and I hung around with her in the nurse's office, so all the kids knew me.'' ''I definitely remember her,'' said Mr. Luba, 38. Both are first-generation Ukrainian-Americans,
title: HABITATS | WEST VILLAGE; Summer Camp, Forever

body: AROUND TOWN ATLANTIC AVENUE ARTWALK From Harlem to Clinton Hill, the chance to peer into artists' studios is a staple of the New York neighborhood spring calendar. They're do-it-yourself affairs: grab a map, stop where you please, talk to the artist or don't. It's your world now; the artists just work here. And they're fine with that. Or at least
title: Spare Times

body: Fear of a dreaded disease has been part of the bargain for years. Shame came slower, as smokers were cast from offices, restaurants and even bars. Now, in New York City, there is yet another scary side effect to smoking: empty pockets. As a new $1.25 state tax took effect on Tuesday, making the combined tax in New York City the nation's highest and
title: Cigarette Tax Arrives Amid Grumbling and Vows

title: MTV's Unscripted Show May Get a Dose of Gritty Brooklyn Reality

body: DEAR DIARY: I knew my friend Anne was better trained for the race when she turned to me in the sixth mile and asked, ''What would be a good side dish to serve with short ribs?'' title: Metropolitan Diary

body: Before sunrise on Tuesday morning, a strange sight began to appear on Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn: a six-foot-tall metal drill bit seemed to emerge from the wooden pier, covered in genuine East River mud and revolving slowly beneath the glow of the Manhattan skyline. On Wednesday it will grow into a 12-foot-tall industrial-looking behemoth
title: Telescope Takes a Long View, to London

body: A 29-year-old man was found shot to death inside a building in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, on Friday, the police said. The body of the man, whose name was not immediately released, was discovered about 2 p.m. inside a building elevator at 423 Baltic Street, in the Gowanus Houses near downtown Brooklyn. He had a gunshot wound to the head, the police
title: Man Is Found Shot to Death in an Elevator

title: In City's Growing Neighborhoods, Public Schools Face Pupil Jam

body: WHEN the time came to pare down her guest list to 50 people, Brigitte Aleman had firm instructions. ''Look at some of these friends,'' she remembers telling her fiancé. ''If we haven't spoken to them in the last year or six months, they're off the list.'' Space was tight at the Miami restaurant where the wedding and reception were to take place,
title: FIELD NOTES; I Take This Cyberpal to Be My Bridesmaid

body: The Philadelphia 76ers got the Detroit Pistons' attention. Then they got steamrolled. The Pistons powered into the second round of the playoffs by crushing Philadelphia, 100-77, on Thursday night, winning the best-of-seven series by four games to two and again demonstrating how good they are when they feel the need to be. Detroit convincingly won
title: N.B.A. ROUNDUP; Quick Start Helps Pistons Eliminate 76ers

body: The ever-lengthening timeline for completing the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn is not just bad news for those who hoped to see the project's basketball arena, office towers and apartment blocks completed quickly. It is also, according to a lawsuit filed Wednesday, illegal. The suit challenges an agreement between the
title: Delays in $4 Billion Brooklyn Development Are Challenged in Tenants' Lawsuit

body: The Police Department gave up about 20,000 of the city's coveted parking placards. The Fire Department lost more than 2,000. The mayor's office gave up 163. Those were some of the most striking numbers in a long-awaited inventory that the city released on Wednesday, showing that it has reduced the number of free-parking placards distributed to law
title: City, True to Mayor's Promise, Slashes Free-Parking Placards

body: In the renamed arena next to the construction zone near the turnpike, the Nets played their final home game -- a nondescript team in a nondescript parking lot, in search of a new identity and a new home. title: NETS 112, BOBCATS 108, O.T.; Nets Are Moving, But Their Direction Remains Unclear

title: THE HUNT; Settling Down, Without Having to Settle

body: After the last massive section of crane slid into place late Sunday afternoon at a construction site in Brooklyn, Thomas Auringer, the owner of the company that pulled off the feat without a hitch, sat on the bed of a pickup across the street, swinging his legs. ''I'm happy,'' he said. ''Very happy. It was a nice, smooth operation.'' The yellow
title: First Crane Jump Since Collapse Is 'Smooth Operation'

body: Throughout New York City's building boom, so-called crane jumps, an intricate procedure in which a crane is jacked up to raise its height, have been a frequent and little-noticed routine at construction sites. But the scene on Saturday at a Brooklyn construction site was anything but routine. City buildings inspectors, safety managers, police
title: Eyes on the Sky at the First Crane Jump Since a Collapse

title: On This Show, Vinny From Lincoln High Is Host

title: Girl Was Dead For Seven Hours Before 911 Call, Doctor Testifies

title: Spare Times Listings

title: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Seeking to Block Atlantic Yards
